edu.biu.scapi.comm.multiPartyComm

Class SocketMultipartyCommunicationSetup

  • java.lang.Object
    • edu.biu.scapi.comm.multiPartyComm.SocketMultipartyCommunicationSetup
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    MultipartyCommunicationSetup, org.apache.commons.exec.TimeoutObserver
    Direct Known Subclasses:
    SSLSocketMultipartyCommunicationSetup

    public class SocketMultipartyCommunicationSetup
extends java.lang.Object
implements MultipartyCommunicationSetup, org.apache.commons.exec.TimeoutObserver
    This class implements a communication between multiple parties using TCP sockets.

    Each created channel contains two sockets; one is used to send messages and one to receive messages.

    This class encapsulates the stage of connecting to other parties. In actuality, the connection to other parties is performed in a few steps, which are not visible to the outside user. These steps are:

    • For each party,
      • For each requested channel, create an actual TCP socket with the other party. This socket is used to send messages
    • Create a server socket that listen to all other parties calls. When a call is received, check who is the connecting party and use the created socket to receive messages from this party.
    • run a protocol that checks if all the necessary connections were set between my party and other parties.
    • In the end return to the calling application a set of connected and ready channels to be used throughout a cryptographic protocol.
    From this point onwards, the application can send and receive messages in each connection as required by the protocol.

    Author:
    Cryptography and Computer Security Research Group Department of Computer Science Bar-Ilan University (Moriya Farbstein)

    • Method Detail

      • prepareForCommunication

        public java.util.Map<PartyData,java.util.Map<java.lang.String,Channel>> prepareForCommunication(java.util.Map<PartyData,java.lang.Object> connectionsPerParty,
                                                                                                long timeOut)
                                                                                         throws java.util.concurrent.TimeoutException
        Description copied from interface: MultipartyCommunicationSetup
        An application that wants to use the communication layer will call this function in order to prepare for communication after providing the required parameters.

        The constructor of the concrete classes should receive the data of the parties participate in the communication. After that, this function initiates the creation of the final actual connections between the parties.

        This function gets a map that contains number of connection that should be established between the current party (application) and any other party in the protocol. The key for the map is the PartyData object contains the data of the other party and the value in the map can be two different things: 1. Integer - the number of connections that should be established between the current party and the party in the key. 2. String[] - the names of the connections that should be established between the current party and the party in the key. Each connection has a unique name, that we call ID. This name used to distinguish between the created connections in order to make it easier and more convenient to understand what is the usage of each connection.

        If this function succeeds, the application may use the send and receive functions of the created channels to pass messages.

        In this function, Nagle's algorithm is disabled; for cryptographic protocols this is typically much better. In order to use the Nagle algorithm, call the enableNagle() function.

        Specified by:
        prepareForCommunication in interface MultipartyCommunicationSetup
        Parameters:
        connectionsPerParty - indicates the amount of connections or the names of connections that should be created between the current application and any other party in the protocol
        timeOut - the maximum amount of time we allow for the connection stage.
        Returns:
        a map contains the connected channels. The key to the map is the PartyData of a the parties on the protocol and the value is the created connections to this party.
        Throws:
        java.util.concurrent.TimeoutException - in case a timeout has occurred before all channels have been connected.

      • enableNagle

        public void enableNagle()
        Description copied from interface: MultipartyCommunicationSetup
        Enables to use Nagle algrithm in the communication.

        By default Nagle algorithm is disabled since it is much better for cryptographic algorithms.

        Specified by:
        enableNagle in interface MultipartyCommunicationSetup

      • timeoutOccured

        public void timeoutOccured(org.apache.commons.exec.Watchdog w)
        This function is called by the infrastructure of the Watchdog if the previously set timeout has passed. (Do not call this function).
        Specified by:
        timeoutOccured in interface org.apache.commons.exec.TimeoutObserver

      • close
